TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE , living in GPE , GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE . The respondent Government are represented by its Agent Mr PERSON , ORG , and its Co - Agent , PERSON , ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

By indictment of CARDINAL DATE the applicant , at that time a practising lawyer , jointly with CARDINAL of his clients , henceforth called ORG , was charged with aggravated breach of trust alleged to have been committed in their roles as manager and/or chairman of the board of CARDINAL companies , owned by ORG over a short period DATE , during which period , they had let the companies purchase CARDINAL industrial properties from a company controlled by ORG at a price substantially above market value , the amount including an agency commission to ORG exceeding MONEY ( ORG ) , whereby the acquiring companies suffered or risked suffering a corresponding financial loss . The companies went bankrupt on DATE .

Moreover the applicant ( and ORG ) was charged with fraud alleged to have been committed in the same period relating to the sale of CARDINAL cars to a person henceforth called ORG under the pretence that the cars were not in pawn .

The applicant and ORG pleaded not guilty on both counts . As regards the second count they claimed that ORG acted in bad faith . Several hearings were held in ORG . During these proceedings ORG and CARDINAL other witnesses were heard , including CARDINAL witnesses henceforth called ORG , ORG and ORG .
The prosecution and the defence agreed not to hear CARDINAL witnesses henceforth called ORG and ORG .

By judgment of DATE ORG of Ballerup ( ORG ret ) convicted the applicant ( and ORG ) . The applicant was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment and deprived of his right to practise law . From the judgment it appears that in order to convict the applicant ( and ORG ) of aggravated breach of trust the court relied partly on the testimonies given by ORG and ORG concerning the contents and aim of some particular transactions these witnesses had with ORG . As regards the charge of fraud it appears that the court relied partly on the testimonies given by ORG and IK concerning the sale of the CARDINAL cars .

The applicant ( and ORG ) appealed against the judgment to ORG of Eastern GPE ( PERSON ) . During these proceedings CARDINAL witnesses were heard , including ORG , ORG , ORG and ORG . As regards these witnesses the applicant expressed doubts during the proceedings in ORG as to their credibility and therefore requested the prosecution to provide information about their criminal records , and that counsel for the defence be allowed to ask questions , in writing , about any pending charges which might have been brought against them concerning financial crime . In accordance with LAW ( PERSON ) this was complied with . ORG and ORG confirmed that charges were brought against them . ORG had previously been convicted of fraud and fraudulent preference .

On DATE the High Court of Eastern Denmark upheld the judgment , but increased the sentence to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . As regards the conviction for aggravated breach of trust ORG referred to the reasoning given by ORG . However , regarding the conviction for fraud ORG relied , in addition to the reasoning given by ORG , on testimony given by a witness who was not heard before ORG .

After the trial in ORG and due to press coverage , the applicant and counsel for the defence , accidentally became aware that within the police a so - called ORG in DATE had composed a note called “ Anti - Social Trade ” ( PERSON ) , henceforth called the note , illustrating a new pattern of crime , and outlining CARDINAL named individuals suspected of being interrelated in a network of financial crimes in GPE , mainly concerning fraudulent trading in connection with deliberate bankruptcy intentions , breaches of laws concerning bookkeeping and accounting in companies , customs and excise fraud committed in connection with car sales , and finally fraud related to the raising of credit secured on real property . Among the persons mentioned in the note were the applicant , GPE , ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG , ORG and ORG . The note contained information about judgments , charges , dropped charges , and mere suspicions against each person in regard to the above criminality , and a statement of their assumed mutual business connections . According to the note it was ascertained that this limited circle , among others , systematically exploited those loopholes and ambiguities in the NORP legislation , which sometimes arise in connection with new legislation and/or reorganisation of administrative procedures .

It appears from the introductory paragraphs of the note that ORG for ORG PERSON ) in DATE decided that ORG was to illustrate this new pattern of crime . ORG was not supposed to go into depth as to bring forth evidence to prove that crimes had been committed , it was merely intended to outline the information available . If the result turned out as expected the purpose was to have a special group appointed from several different police units , as none could manage the task alone for resource reasons . This group was then to make concrete investigations with the targeted attempt to have proceedings instituted against the individuals in question .
The note was distributed to ORG , ORG ( GPE ) , the ORG Commissioner of Police ( GPE ) and the various police districts .
The prosecution did not submit the note , either to the applicant , or to the court during the criminal proceedings against the applicant

The applicant requested leave to appeal against the above judgment of ORG to ORG ( Højesteret ) . With a view to this counsel for the defence asked the prosecution , on DATE , to submit a copy of the above note . However , access to the note was refused by ORG on DATE , by ORG on DATE and by ORG ( PERSON ) on DATE .
The applicant then brought legal proceedings before ORG of Eastern GPE against ORG requesting that counsel for the defence be given access to the note .
Before ORG as regard the nature of the note in general ORG referred to its reply of CARDINAL DATE to a question from ORG , according to which inter alia :
“ The note has been drafted by ORG ... mainly for use in deliberations on how to rank the cases in order of priority , on combinations of resources and on prosecution competence ...

On the basis of the note ... concrete investigative steps were taken , and that was the primary purpose of the note ... several of the individuals referred to in the note have been prosecuted and a number of them have been convicted .

The note contains a compilation of a series of particulars and suspicions ... concerning CARDINAL named individuals . The note was thus a good foundation , in an investigating context , for the police and the prosecutors to ensure better co - ordination of the investigation and the commencement of prosecution in cases regarding financial crime ... ”

ORG of LOC found for ORG . The applicant appealed against the judgment to ORG , before which the prosecutor in the applicant ’s trial as a witness stated that he was given a copy of the note as general material like all other prosecutors working for ORG , but since the note did not form part of any specific case , he did not use it in connection with his work on the applicant ’s case .
ORG found for the applicant on DATE , stating as follows :

“ According to section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of ORG the defence is entitled to have access to material produced by the police . As stated by ORG in his notice No . CARDINAL of DATE , to come within the scope of this provision , the material needs to have some connection with the relevant trial . However , it does not have to be of real importance to the investigation or to the possible continuation of the prosecution .

From the Minister of ORG ’s answer of CARDINAL DATE to ORG it appears , among other things , that as a result of the “ Anti - Social Trade ” note and in accordance with the main aim of the note , specific measures and investigation were initiated .

ORG does not dispute that the applicant , the co - accused and some of the witnesses who were heard during the applicant ’s trial figure in the note , including the mutual relationship among some of them . The investigations were initiated shortly after the note was composed , and both the persons in charge of the investigations and the prosecutor were in possession of the note .

In these circumstances , ORG considers that the note has such a connection with the applicant ’s trial that the defence is entitled to have access to it cf . section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of ORG . ”

A copy of the note was hereafter sent to the applicant ’s counsel on DATE . Subsequently , in support of his request for leave to appeal the applicant alleged that LAW had been violated , notably as the principle of equality of arms had not been complied with . In this respect he referred to the content of the note , with which both the police and the prosecution were familiar , but which was not available to counsel for the defence during the criminal trial .
On DATE ORG refused the applicant ’s request for leave to appeal to ORG for which reason the High Court judgment of DATE became final .
